headline: CNN 10
subHeadline: China`s Population Shrinks For The First Time Since The 1960s; Egg Prices Soar. Aired 4-4:10a ET

utterances.speaker: MARC STEWART, CNN INTERNATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: The headline is significant. China`s population shrank last year, the first time this hashappened in more than 60 years, a decline of about 850,000 people. Let`s break this down and look at some of the reasons why. First, priorities are changing. We`re getting married later and some young people are not having children at all. In addition, Beijing held a controversial one-child policy until 2015, but it was relaxed because of concerns about the population. In 2021, three children were then allowed, and a plan was released to strengthen maternity leave and to offer tax deductions. In addition to all of this, the cost of living in China is high, so is education. And then there`s just general economic uncertainty, that can all impact decision making. So, what are the takeaways from this? The United Nations is predicting India will surpass China to become the most populated country this year. And then there are the economic implications. This means an aging workforce without a pipeline into the future that could impact productivity and in turn economic success. Chinese leader Xi Jinping has raised these demographic challenges saying boosting birth rates and addressing the cost of raising a child will be part of future policy. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Ten-second triviaWhich of these words comes from a Latin term meaning bird? Auto, aerial, avian, or able? Avian is your answer here. It can be traced all the way back to a Latin word avis meaning bird. Did you know there`s currently an egg shortage and now the prices of eggs are no yolk? One of the culprits is an outbreak of the avian flu, a virus mostly affecting birds. According to the U.S. Department of Agriculture, the average price for a dozen eggs in California is more than seven bucks. It was just $2.35 a year ago. And one of my CNN teammates Maya in New York City, she spent $12 on a dozen eggs yesterday. That`s a dollar per egg y`all. At these prices, I`m not sure those omelettes are all they`re cracked up to be. Here`s CNN business and politics correspondent Vanessa Yurkevich who tells us exactly what`s causing the shortage and these super high prices. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) VANESSA YURKEVICH, CNN BUSINESS AND POLITICS CORRESPONDENT (voice-over):  In chilly Palmer, Alaska, the demand for chickens and their eggs is heating up.

utterances.speaker: DOON DYER, OWNER, POLARIS FARM
utterances.sentences: I was already sold out even before the egg shortage. I was - I was selling everything I had.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: If you`ve been to the grocery store recently, you may have noticed fewer eggs and higher prices, up about 11 percent last month onaverage from November, up nearly 60 percent in the last year. $11.49 for a dozen eggs in New York, $10.99 in Hawaii.

utterances.speaker: SHANTEL ROLDAN, MANOA, HI RESIDENT
utterances.sentences: I think it`s ridiculous for it to be that much.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: The highly pathogenic avian influenza, or avian flu, is largely to blame. Nearly 58 million birds and climbing have died across 47 statesin the last year, a result of the deadly virus. Wild birds can carry the disease and spread it to domestic flocks when they migrate.

utterances.speaker: CHELSEA CARRIGAN, OWNER, RED BARN FARM
utterances.sentences: One wild bird coming into their chicken run and the next thing you know, 10 birds, 20 birds, 30 birds,they`re just dropping dead.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Some states now recommending that all poultry be maintained indoors. Poultry and bird shows, canceled. And biosecurity around chickens,strictly enforced.

utterances.speaker: SARAH SCHNEIDER, OWNER, EGG SHOP
utterances.sentences: The avian flu is serious.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Egg Shop, with two cafes in New York City, is struggling with prices on their main ingredient. The fall migration of wild birds sentavian flu cases spiking again.

utterances.speaker: SCHNEIDER
utterances.sentences: We go through 7,000 to 9,000 eggs a week. So, it`s a significant amount of eggs. And in the last couple weeks they`ve jumped ashigh as 60 percent.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: How have you been able to absorb the high price increases of eggs?

utterances.speaker: SCHNEIDER
utterances.sentences: Unfortunately, we have raised all of our prices about 10 percent on our menu items.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: For some, the increased cost is too much. Baked after Dark bakery in Nebraska will close its doors this weekend.

utterances.speaker: STACEY JOHNSON, OWNER, BAKED AFTER DARK
utterances.sentences: I think about what our family could afford to pay for a cookie. I take that into consideration. We can`tcharge $5 a cookie.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: The ripple effect goes beyond restaurants and bakeries. Take a look around the grocery store. Items that use eggs, like mayonnaise, are up11.8 percent in the last year.

utterances.speaker: ANGELO PULEO, SUPERVISOR, MORTON WILLIAMS SUPERMARKETS
utterances.sentences: From the flu to the increases in inflation, all combined together with the shortage, it isthe perfect storm.

utterances.speaker: VERA NEWHOUSE, NYC SHOPPER
utterances.sentences: And I definitely have seen the prices shoot up recently.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Does that stop you from making the purchase?

utterances.speaker: NEWHOUSE
utterances.sentences: No, not at all.I`m just buying things to make a chicken cutlet. And you need eggs as the basis for that too. It`s one of the reasons why there`s no way not to purchase them. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Up next, we`re headed to Australia where every year in the Great Barrier Reef, corals spawn following a full moon. This is crucial becausescientists said that rising temperatures have led to bleaching, and more than percent of the reefs surveyed last year. Coral that was once vibrant with pulchritudinous colors they`re now colorless. Well, that does not mean though that the coral is dead just yet and a new technique just might bring the beauty back. Let`s head down under the waves Down Under to learn more. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: SUBTITLE
utterances.sentences: For the past three years, researchers have used the annual spawning to test a restoration method called "coral seeding".

utterances.speaker: CATHIE PAGE, AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF MARINE SCIENCE
utterances.sentences: Coral spawning is the once in a year opportunity to replenish. So, it`s a really valuable timefor the reef but also a really important time for us to do our research. We allow coral lobby to settle onto 3D printed structures that we then deploy to the reef, and it`s an opportunity for us to boost the number of very young corals on the reef and potentially boost rates of recovery on those reefs in the future. They have some protective features that might stop fish from biting them or algae from over growing them or sediment from settling on them.

utterances.speaker: SUBTITLE
utterances.sentences: So far, the technique has exceeded expectations.

utterances.speaker: PAGE
utterances.sentences: We`re building year on year on our research in this area, trialing different designs one year and then building on those in the next.

utterances.speaker: SUBTITLE
utterances.sentences: The scientists seeded hundreds of corals during the reef`s 2022 mass spawning.They hope their research will help restore reefs in Australia and eventually worldwide. (END VIDEOTAPE)
